case_name: Zila Parishad, Kheri v. Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1893 and 1894 of 1968 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1967 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Special Appeals Nos. 60 and 61 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1893 and 1894 of 1968. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1967 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Special Appeals Nos. 60 and 61 of 1966 and Civil Appeal No. 172 of 1969.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 172 of 1969 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 23, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Special Appeal No. 22 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 172 of 1969. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated April 23, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Special Appeal No. 22 of 1966. Kripa Shankar Bazela, Naunit Lal and Swaranjit Sodhi, for the appellant  in all the appeals .

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. is a company manufacturing sugar with factory situated in Gola Gokaran Nath in District Kheri in the State of U.P.

anchor.surface_text: The Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. is a companypany manufacturing sugar. Its factory is situate in Gola Gokaran Nath in District Kheri in the State of U.P. For manufacturing sugar the companypany purchases sugarcane in the District of Kheri.

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. purchases sugarcane in the District of Kheri.

anchor.surface_text: For manufacturing sugar the companypany purchases sugarcane in the District of Kheri. It maintains some staff and also makes certain advances to cultivators within the rural area of the said district.

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. maintains some staff and makes certain advances to cultivators within the rural area of the said district.

anchor.surface_text: It maintains some staff and also makes certain advances to cultivators within the rural area of the said district. It was assessed to what is known as the circumstances and property tax.

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. was assessed to circumstances and property tax under s. 114 of the District Boards Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: It was assessed to what is known as the circumstances and property tax. The relevant provision under which this tax companyld be levied was s. 114 of the District Boards Act, 1922 which was repealed by the U.P.

facts.text: District Boards Act, 1922 was repealed by the U.P. Kshettra Samitis and Zila Parishads Adhiniyam, 1961, which enacted similar provision s. 121.

anchor.surface_text: Kishettr a Samitis and Zila Parishads Adhiniyam, 1961, hereinafter referred to as the Adhiniyam but a similar provision, s. 121 was enacted in that statute. The material portion of S. 121 is as follows -

facts.text: s. 121(a) of the Adhiniyam allows tax on any person residing or carrying on business in the rural area for a total period of at least six months in the year under assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Conditions and restrictions for tax on Circumstances and Property.-The power of a Parishad to impose a tax on circumstances and property shall be subject to the following companyditions and restrictions, namely-  a  the tax may be imposed on any person residing or carrying on business in the rural area provided that such person has so resided or carried on business for a total period of at least six months in the year under assessment

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. objected to the levy of the tax but assessing authorities did not accept objections and made assessment for 1961-1962 and 1962-63.

anchor.surface_text: b  The companypany objected to the levy of the aforesaid tax but the assessing authorities did number accept its, objections and made the assessment for the years 1961-1962 and 1962-63.

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. filed appeal to Commissioner, Lucknow Division, who held that the tax had been wrongly imposed.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany filed an appeal to the Commissioner, Lucknow Division, who held that the tax had been wrongly imposed. Thereupon the Zila Parishad, Kheri, filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the order of the Commissioner.

facts.text: Zila Parishad, Kheri filed petition under Art. 226 challenging Commissioner's order; learned single Judge dismissed it.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the Zila Parishad, Kheri, filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the order of the Commissioner. A learned single Judge of the High Court dismissed that petition.

facts.text: Zila Parishad took matter by special appeal to Division Bench, which also failed.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was taken by way of special appeal to a Division Bench. That appeal also failed.

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd.'s factory is situated outside the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad.

anchor.surface_text: whose factory for manufacturing sugar was situate outside the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad. On behalf of the Zila Parishad it was maintained that the companypany was purchasing sugarcane in the rural area within its jurisdiction

facts.text: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. purchases sugarcane in rural area within Zila Parishad's jurisdiction for manufacturing sugar in its factory outside.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the Zila Parishad it was maintained that the companypany was purchasing sugarcane in the rural area within its jurisdiction for the purpose of manufacturing sugar in its factory and since the purchases were made within the rural area it was carrying on business in that area

facts.text: It was not disputed before the learned single Judge that the business of the company consisted of manufacturing sugar.

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed before the learned single Judge that the business of the companypany companysisted of manufacturing sugar. facts.text: The short question is whether on admitted and undisputed facts tax could be levied under s.121 on company whose factory is outside Zila Parishad jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The short question which the High Court was called upon to decide and which has to be determined by us is whether on the admitted and undisputed facts any tax companyld be levied under s. 121 of the Adhiniyam on the companypany.

facts.text: Zila Parishad contended that continuous and regular activity of buying sugarcane constituted carrying on business in rural areas.

anchor.surface_text: Before us it has been companytended on behalf of the Zila Parishad that the companytinuous and regular activity of buying sugarcane which extended for the period mentioned in clause  a  of S. 121 of the Adhiniyam companystituted carrying on of business in the rural areas from where the sugarcane was purchased.

issues.text: whether on the admitted and undisputed facts any tax could be levied under s. 121 of the Adhiniyam on the company whose factory for manufacturing sugar was situate outside the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad

anchor.surface_text: The short question which the High Court was called upon to decide and which has to be determined by us is whether on the admitted and undisputed facts any tax could be levied under s. 121 of the Adhiniyam on the company.

issues.text: whether the company was carrying on business in the rural area within the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad when the activity attributed to it consisted of regularly buying or purchasing sugarcane for the business of manufacturing sugar in its factory which was outside the rural area

anchor.surface_text: All that has to be decided, therefore, is whether the company was carrying on business in the rural area within the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad when the activity attributed to it consisted of regularly buying or purchasing sugarcane for the business of manufacturing sugar in its factory

arguments.claim: The company was purchasing sugarcane in the rural area within Zila Parishad's jurisdiction for manufacturing sugar in its factory outside, so it was carrying on business in that area and liable to tax under s.121

anchor.surface_text: whose factory for manufacturing sugar was situate outside the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad. On behalf of the Zila Parishad it was maintained that the companypany was purchasing sugarcane in the rural area within its jurisdiction for the purpose of manufacturing sugar in its factory and since the purchases were made within the rural area it was carrying on business in that area and was thus liable to the levy and payment of tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: Mere purchase of raw material does not constitute carrying on business where manufacturing occurs outside

arguments.claim: In the same business it may be necessary to purchase machinery, spare parts, fuel wood from different places but business of manufacturing not carried on at those purchase places; similarly sugarcane purchase does not mean business carried on there

anchor.surface_text: For that purpose it was essential to purchase the raw material at the mill gate and in the mofussil area including the rural area in the district of Kheri. The reasoning of the learned Judge was that in the same business it may be necessary for the companypany to purchase some machinery or spare parts from different places. in the companyntry or to purchase fuel wood and lubricating oil from different places. It could hardly be said that the business of manufacturing sugar was being companyducted or carried on at all those places from where these companymodities or articles were purchased. Merely because the purchase of sugarcane was essential for the carrying on of business of manufacturing sugar it did number mean that any business was being carried on in the places where the sugarcane was being purchased.

arguments.claim: Cases under Income tax Act distinguished; question viewed from business man standpoint; manufacturing sugar but collecting sugarcane from multiple districts does not mean business carried on in those districts

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench distinguished the cases which had been relied upon on behalf of the Zila Parishad arising under the Income tax Act, 1922. It was pointed out that the question had to be looked at from the standpoint of a business man. If a person manufactured sugar in the district of Kheri but companylected sugarcane which was a raw material from half a dozen districts it companyld hardly be said, from the point of view of business, that it was being carried on in the various districts from where the material was being acquired.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees with this approach

arguments.claim: Continuous and regular activity of buying sugarcane extending for the period in s.121(a) constituted carrying on business in rural areas

arguments.claim: In Chas J Webb case, purchase of raw material constituted an operation under s.42(3) Income tax Act, taxable; analogous here

anchor.surface_text: Reliance has been placed on a Bench decision of the East Punjab High Court in Chas J. Webb Sons Co. Inc. Philadelphia v. Commissioner of Income tax, East Punjab 1 . There the assessee companypany which was incorporated in the United States of America was carrying on the business of manufacturing carpets in America. Its only business in British India was to purchase, through its agents in  1  18 I.T.R. 33. British India, wool as raw material for use in the manufacture of carpets. The companypany was sought to be assessed in respect of its income from such purchases of raw material under S. 42 3  of the Indian Income tax Act, 1922.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rated in the United States of America was carrying on the business of manufacturing carpets in America. Its only business in British India was to purc

arguments.court_reasoning: s.42 deems income from 'business connection' and 'operations' in British India; different from 'carrying on business' in s.121 Adhiniyam

arguments.claim: Chas J Webb case distinguishable as s.42 Income tax Act different provision from s.121 Adhiniyam; 'operation' includes purchase but not same as 'carrying on business'

anchor.surface_text: It was held that the mere purchase of raw material in British India was an operation within the meaning of S. 42 3  of that Act and that the profits which arose out of such purchases were taxable. Section 42 of the Income tax Act was a totally different provision. According to it all income, profits or gains accruing or arising whether directly or indirectly through or from any business companynection in British India were to be deemed to be income accruing or arising within British India.

arguments.claim: Per Mukherjea J in Ahmedebhai case, continuous activity like buying raw material is part of business only if separate profit ascertainable; here no separate profit from sugarcane purchase

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income tax, Bombay v. Ahme- debhai Umarbhai Co., Bombay 1 , Mukherjea J.,  as he then was  observed as follows - A man may carry on the trade of a seller or purchaser of goods he may be a manufacturer of goods or an exporter or importer of the same. Each of these would be a business within the meaning of the Act. Suppose for example, that he companybines of all these acti- vities and carried on a business which includes manufacturing, selling and also exporting and importing of goods. Can it number be said that each one of these activities is a part of the business which he carries on ? I agree with Mr. Munshi that if a particular process or activity of a companytinuous character can be distinguished from other processes and if a separate profit can be ascertained and allotted in respect to the same, there is numberreason why it should number be regarded as a part of the business which yields income or profits.

arguments.claim: In Zila Parishad Muzaffarnagar case, firm crushed sugarcane to rab (saleable commodity) in rural area so carrying on business there; analogous

anchor.surface_text: It is futile to refer to all the other cases on which learned companynsel for the Zila Parishad has relied as they are totally distinguishable on facts except to numberice the decision in Zila Parishad, Muzaffarnagar Anr. v. Jugal Kishore Ram Swarup Anr.  1  There a firm had set up crushers in certain rural areas from where it purchased sugarcane. The sugarcane was crushed and companyverted into juice. That juice was sent to the town of Mirzapur for being pressed into sugar. The High Court was of the view that the juice which was called Rab was a saleable companymodity in itself and was also a finished product.

arguments.court_reasoning: Here sugarcane merely purchased, not subjected to any process creating saleable commodity or finished product

arguments.claim: Sugarcane purchased was not subjected to any process creating saleable commodity or finished product that could earn profits, so no carrying on business

anchor.surface_text: The sugarcane which was being purchased by the companypany was number subjected to any such process by which any such companymodity or finished product came into existence which by itself companyld earn profits.

holdings.text: The company was not carrying on business in the rural area within the jurisdiction of the Zila Parishad merely by purchasing sugarcane there, as no process was applied to create a saleable commodity or finished product.

anchor.surface_text: The sugarcane which was being purchased by the companypany was number subjected to any such process by which any such companymodity or finished product came into existence which by itself companyld earn profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from Zila Parishad Muzaffarnagar where sugarcane was crushed into saleable rab; here sugarcane only purchased without processing or separate profit generation.

holdings.text: No tax can be levied under s.121 of the Adhiniyam on the company whose factory is outside the Zila Parishad jurisdiction based on admitted facts of sugarcane purchases.

anchor.surface_text: The short question which the High Court was called upon to decide and which has to be determined by us is whether on the admitted and undisputed facts any tax companyld be levied under s. 121 of the Adhiniyam on the companypany.

holdings.reasoning_summary: On admitted facts, purchasing raw material does not amount to carrying on business; affirms lower courts' view that tax wrongly imposed.

holdings.text: Chas J Webb case provides no assistance for interpreting 'carrying on business' in s.121(a) of the Adhiniyam as s.42 of Income-tax Act deems 'operations' like purchases differently.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see how any assistance can be derived from the above case for the purpose of deciding the meaning of the word carrying on business used in s. 121  a  of the Adhiniyam.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.42 deems income from business connection and operations in British India; distinct from territorial requirement of 'carrying on business' for tax under Adhiniyam.

holdings.text: Purchasing sugarcane is not a separable business activity with distinct profits under the test in Ahmedbhai Umarbhai case.

anchor.surface_text: These observations can hardly be of any avail to the Zila Parishad. The buying of raw material in the shape of sugarcane may be a process or activity of a companytinuous character but even according  1  1953 S.C.R. 335, 376. to the test laid down by Mukherjea J., which related to entirely different statutory provisions and facts it cannot be said that the companypany was making any separate profits or income by means Of purchasing sugarcane.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Mukherjea J.'s test: continuous activity is part of business only if separate profit ascertainable; sugarcane purchase yields no separate profit.

holdings.text: Zila Parishad Muzaffarnagar case is distinguishable as there sugarcane was processed into saleable rab, unlike mere purchase here.

anchor.surface_text: The facts that have been stated clearly establish the distinguishing features from the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In that case, activity created saleable commodity for gain; here no such conversion or profit-making process in rural area.

anchor.surface_text: The short question which the High Court was called upon to decide and which has to be determined by us is whether on the admitted and undisputed facts any tax companyld be levied under s. 121 of the Adhiniyam on the companypany.

The facts that have been stated clearly establish the distinguishing features from the present case. anchor.surface_text: These observations can hardly be of any avail to the Zila Parishad.
